message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a feeding problem due to respiratory distress, which can be caused by patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). The precordial murmur heard is also consistent with PDA, as it is loudest at S2 and radiates to the left clavicle. A congenital mitral insufficiency or supracristal ventricular septal defect with aortic regurgitation would have different murmurs, while ruptured congenital sinus of Valsalva aneurysm is rare and usually presents in adulthood.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs are suggestive of patent ductus arteriosus, which includes feeding difficulty, rapid breathing, sweating while feeding, poor weight gain, and a continuous murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border. Congenital mitral insufficiency will have a systolic murmur best heard at the apex. The second sound is obscured in both patent ductus arteriosus and supracristal ventricular septal defect with aortic regurgitation, but the latter will have a harsh ejection systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border. Ruptured congenital sinus of Valsalva aneurysm can cause heart failure, but it is uncommon in infants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs suggest a congenital heart disease, and among the options, the best fit is patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). PDA causes increased pulmonary blood flow, which can lead to pulmonary congestion and wheezing, and the murmur of PDA is continuous from S1 to S2, with maximal intensity at S2. Other options have different types of murmurs or do not fit the symptoms and signs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of rapid breathing, sweating, and difficulty feeding, along with bilateral wheezing and a heart murmur suggest that the most likely diagnosis is patent ductus arteriosus. The location of the murmur over the second left intercostal space and radiation to the left clavicle further supports this diagnosis. Congenital mitral insufficiency would have a different location for the murmur, and supracristal ventricular septal defect and ruptured congenital sinus of Valsalva aneurysm would not cause the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including fast respiratory rate, sweaty breastfeeding, and bilateral wheezing, suggest the most likely diagnosis as Patent ductus arteriosus. The precordial murmur, maximal intensity heard over the second left intercostal space, and radiating to the left clavicle also supports this diagnosis. The other options for this question are less likely to present with these symptoms and murmur characteristics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and symptoms of feeding difficulty, rapid breathing, and sweating suggest respiratory distress. The bilateral wheezing on chest auscultation indicates a respiratory problem, while the precordial murmur and location suggest a cardiac problem. The most likely cause is patent ductus arteriosus, which is characterized by a continuous machinery-like murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border or the lower left cervical region. It may be asymptomatic or may present with feeding difficulty or failure to thrive, rapid breathing, sweating, and fatigue. The first heart sound (S1) is normal, while the second heart sound (S2) is obscured by the murmur, which is consistent with patent ductus arteriosus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of rapid breathing and sweating while nursing, as well as the presence of bilateral wheezing, suggest respiratory distress. The precordial murmur that starts immediately after S1, reaches its maximal intensity at the end of systole, and wanes during late diastole, is characteristic of patent ductus arteriosus. None of the other options present with this typical murmur or history of respiratory distress.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the symptoms and history, the most likely diagnosis is patent ductus arteriosus. This is supported by the presence of bilateral wheezing, rapid breathing, and feeding difficulty, which are all symptoms associated with heart failure. The precordial murmur that starts with the onset of the first heart sound and radiates to the left clavicle is also consistent with a patent ductus arteriosus. Congenital mitral insufficiency and ruptured congenital sinus of Valsalva aneurysm are unlikely based on the presentation. Supracristal ventricular septal defect with aortic regurgitation would present with a louder murmur and would be heard more in the right upper sternal border.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs, such as feeding difficulty, rapid breathing, sweating, bilateral wheezing on chest auscultation, and a precordial murmur best heard over the second left intercostal space that obscures the second heart sound suggest the most likely diagnosis is Patent ductus arteriosus. All other options do not have a precordial murmur that starts immediately after the onset of S1 and obscures S2.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infant's symptoms of feeding difficulty, rapid breathing, and profuse sweating suggest a diagnosis of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). The chest auscultation and precordial murmur also support this diagnosis. Congenital mitral insufficiency, supracristal ventricular septal defect with aortic regurgitation, and ruptured congenital sinus of Valsalva aneurysm are less likely based on the symptoms and physical findings.
